targets.expr:
max(
  redis_uptime_in_seconds{
    app_name=~"$app_name",
    app_version=~"$app_version",
    region=~"$region",
    cluster_id=~"$cluster_id",
    k8s_node_name=~"$k8s_node_name",
    k8s_pod_name=~"$k8s_pod_name",
    env=~"$env"
  }
)

(
  sum(
    redis_connected_clients{
      app_name=~"$app_name",
      app_version=~"$app_version",
      region=~"$region",
      cluster_id=~"$cluster_id",
      k8s_node_name=~"$k8s_node_name",
      k8s_pod_name=~"$k8s_pod_name",
      env=~"$env"
    }
  )
  /
  sum(
    redis_config_maxclients{
      app_name=~"$app_name",
      app_version=~"$app_version",
      region=~"$region",
      cluster_id=~"$cluster_id",
      k8s_node_name=~"$k8s_node_name",
      k8s_pod_name=~"$k8s_pod_name",
      env=~"$env"
    }
  )
)

sum(
  redis_connected_clients{
    app_name=~"$app_name",
    app_version=~"$app_version",
    region=~"$region",
    cluster_id=~"$cluster_id",
    k8s_node_name=~"$k8s_node_name",
    k8s_pod_name=~"$k8s_pod_name",
    env=~"$env"
  }
)

sum(
  redis_db_keys{
    app_name=~"$app_name",
    app_version=~"$app_version",
    region=~"$region",
    cluster_id=~"$cluster_id",
    k8s_node_name=~"$k8s_node_name",
    k8s_pod_name=~"$k8s_pod_name",
    env=~"$env"
  }
)

panels.description:
Since we are measuring sum(rate(...seconds_total)), the unit is "seconds per second". This can be conceptually tricky, but it's powerful:

    0.1s: This Workload spends 10% of its time processing this type of workload.

    1.0s: This workload is consuming 1 full CPU core's worth of time continuously.

    2.5s: This workload is consuming 2.5 cores (total, across all the nodes).

targets.expr:
sum(
  ${rate_func}(
    redis_commands_duration_seconds_total{
      cmd=~"get|mget|hget|hgetall|lrange|smembers|scard|zrange|zcard|exists|ttl|ping|hexists|info",
      app_name=~"$app_name",
      app_version=~"$app_version",
      region=~"$region",
      cluster_id=~"$cluster_id",
      k8s_node_name=~"$k8s_node_name",
      k8s_pod_name=~"$k8s_pod_name",
      env=~"$env"
    }[$__rate_interval]
  )
)

panels.title: Read Workload

panels.description:
Since we are measuring sum(rate(...seconds_total)), the unit is "seconds per second". This can be conceptually tricky, but it's powerful:

    0.1s: This Workload spends 10% of its time processing this type of workload.

    1.0s: This workload is consuming 1 full CPU core's worth of time continuously.

    2.5s: This workload is consuming 2.5 cores (total, across all the nodes).

    redis_commands_duration_seconds_total{

panels.title: Write Workload

/

    env=~"$env"
  }
)

panels.description:
User CPU: This represents time the processor spends executing your application code.

    High User CPU means your application is busy processing data.

System CPU: This represents time the processor spends in the Kernel.

    This is overhead from the Operating System, primarily handling Network I/O (reading/writing TCP packets) and Disk I/O. High System CPU often indicates a bottleneck in networking or disk speed.

Note on "Children": This metric includes CPU used by Background Processes (Children). In Redis, these child processes are spawned to handle persistence tasks like RDB Snapshotting or AOF Rewriting. Spikes in this graph often correlate with backup operations.

targets.expr:
sum(
  ${rate_func}(
    redis_cpu_sys_children_seconds_total{
      app_name=~"$app_name",
      app_version=~"$app_version",
      region=~"$region",
      cluster_id=~"$cluster_id",
      k8s_node_name=~"$k8s_node_name",
      k8s_pod_name=~"$k8s_pod_name",
      env=~"$env"
    }[$__rate_interval]
  )
  +
  ${rate_func}(
    redis_cpu_sys_seconds_total{
      app_name=~"$app_name",
      app_version=~"$app_version",
      region=~"$region",
      cluster_id=~"$cluster_id",
      k8s_node_name=~"$k8s_node_name",
      k8s_pod_name=~"$k8s_pod_name",
      env=~"$env"
    }[$__rate_interval]
  )
)

sum(
  rate(
    redis_cpu_user_children_seconds_total{
      app_name=~"$app_name",
      app_version=~"$app_version",
      region=~"$region",
      cluster_id=~"$cluster_id",
      k8s_node_name=~"$k8s_node_name",
      k8s_pod_name=~"$k8s_pod_name",
      env=~"$env"
    }[$__rate_interval]
  )
  +
  rate(
    redis_cpu_user_seconds_total{
      app_name=~"$app_name",
      app_version=~"$app_version",
      region=~"$region",
      cluster_id=~"$cluster_id",
      k8s_node_name=~"$k8s_node_name",
      k8s_pod_name=~"$k8s_pod_name",
      env=~"$env"
    }[$__rate_interval]
  )
)

panels.title: CPU Utilization

targets.expr:
sum(
  redis_blocked_clients{
    app_name=~"$app_name",
    app_version=~"$app_version",
    region=~"$region",
    cluster_id=~"$cluster_id",
    k8s_node_name=~"$k8s_node_name",
    k8s_pod_name=~"$k8s_pod_name",
    env=~"$env"
  }
)

list.description:
This variable controls the mathematical function used to calculate per-second rates across the dashboard.

    Overview (rate): Calculates the average rate over the entire time interval. Best for spotting trends, capacity planning, and long-term views.

    Debug (irate): Calculates the "instant" rate based on the last two data points. Best for high-resolution troubleshooting and catching micro-spikes.

 Warning: irate should only be used when zoomed in to < 1 hour. On longer time ranges (e.g., 7 days), irate ignores most data points between pixels and will provide a misleading representation of your traffic.
list.label: Mode
list.name: rate_func
